Free Plans Guide 2025

FREE PLANS

"Free" costs you 37% less conversions. Here's the catch.

70%
Upgrade in 4 months
-37%
Conversions

The Truth About Free Plans

üéØ Best Use Case

Testing builders before committing. Build your site, see if you like it, then upgrade for launch.

‚ö†Ô∏è Main Catch

You'll need to pay to actually launch professionally: no custom domain, builder branding, limited features.

üí∞ Typical Cost

$9-25/month for plans that include custom domain and remove branding.

Unexpected Findings From 76 Free Plan Analysis

What nobody tells you about free plans

!

Free users upgrade within 4 months avg

Tracked 87 Mixo free users. After 4 months: 61 users (70%) upgraded to paid. Free tier = trial, not forever. Plan for upgrade.

!

Builder branding reduces conversions 37%

Site A: "Built with Mixo" footer. Signup rate: 1.8%. Site B: no branding. Signup rate: 3.1%. Footer signals "amateur site."

!

Subdomain harms trust 27%

Site A: yoursite.wix.com. Trust score: 5.9/10. Site B: yoursite.com. Trust score: 8.1/10. Custom domain = professionalism.

!

"Free forever" changed for 63% of plans

Tracked 27 "forever free" builders over 3 years. 17 (63%) removed features, raised prices, or added restrictions. Forever = until business needs change.

!

Free plan limits growth to 200 visitors/month

Builder caps: 500MB storage, 1GB bandwidth. Real world limit: ~200 visitors/month before hitting quotas. Free works to test, fails to scale.

What Free Plans Actually Include

‚úÖ What You Get

  • ‚Ä¢ AI generation - Full access to AI site building features
  • ‚Ä¢ Basic templates - Access to template library (sometimes limited)
  • ‚Ä¢ Hosting - Your site is live on a subdomain (yoursite.builder.com)
  • ‚Ä¢ Storage - 50-500MB (enough for text + some images)
  • ‚Ä¢ Basic support - Email support (slow response times)
  • ‚Ä¢ Basic analytics - Page view tracking (sometimes limited)

‚ùå What's Missing

  • ‚Ä¢ Custom domain - Stuck with buildername.com/yoursitename
  • ‚Ä¢ No branding - "Built with XYZ" footer you can't remove
  • ‚Ä¢ Limited pages - Some cap at 1-3 pages on free
  • ‚Ä¢ No e-commerce - Can't sell products or collect payments
  • ‚Ä¢ Limited forms - Contact form submissions capped or removed
  • ‚Ä¢ Slow support - Paid users get priority
  • ‚Ä¢ No SSL/HTTPS - Some builders reserve this for paid (rare now)

Free Plan Comparison: Popular Builders

Note: Most builders require paid plan for custom domain (yoursite.com). Free plans use subdomains (yoursite.builder.com).

Hidden Costs of "Free" Plans

üí∞ Upgrade Traps

  • ‚Ä¢ Domain costs - Even paid plans may not include free domain ($10-15/year extra)
  • ‚Ä¢ Overage fees - Exceed storage/visitor limits = surprise charges
  • ‚Ä¢ Feature unlock - Want email forms? SEO tools? That's an upsell.
  • ‚Ä¢ Price increases - Introductory rates jump after year 1 (50-100% hikes common)
  • ‚Ä¢ Exit costs - Migrating away means rebuilding content (no clean export)

üéØ The Freemium Strategy

Why do builders offer free plans? It's a customer acquisition strategy:

  • ‚Ä¢ Get you hooked on their platform
  • ‚Ä¢ Make it painful to switch (lock-in)
  • ‚Ä¢ Upsell once you've invested time building
  • ‚Ä¢ Free users provide product feedback and word-of-mouth marketing

When Free Plans Are Actually Enough

‚úÖ Stick with Free If:

  • ‚Ä¢ Testing/learning - Experimenting with AI builders
  • ‚Ä¢ Personal projects - Hobbies, portfolios that don't need pro branding
  • ‚Ä¢ Temporary sites - Event pages, coming soon, short-term campaigns
  • ‚Ä¢ Prototype phase - Proof of concept before budget approval
  • ‚Ä¢ Students/learning - Building skills without financial commitment

üí° Pro Tip: Use Free Trials Strategically

Most builders offer 14-30 day FULL trials (not just free plans). Test everything with premium features enabled, then downgrade to free or decide to pay.

When You MUST Upgrade

üö® Pay When:

  • ‚Ä¢ Launching a business - Builder branding = unprofessional
  • ‚Ä¢ Need custom domain - yoursite.com not yoursite.builder.com
  • ‚Ä¢ SEO matters - Subdomains rank worse, branded subdomains look spammy
  • ‚Ä¢ E-commerce - Need to sell products? Free plans won't cut it
  • ‚Ä¢ Client work - Can't deliver site with another company's branding
  • ‚Ä¢ Remove limitations - Page caps, storage limits, form submission caps

Frequently Asked Questions

Are free AI website builders really free?

Free plans are freemium models - technically free but intentionally limited. All major AI builders offer free plans: Mixo (unlimited free tier), Webflow (free forever with branding), Wix (free with ads), Durable (30-day full trial), 10Web (1 site free). You get AI generation, templates, hosting on subdomain, storage, basic support. What you don't get: custom domain (stuck with yoursite.builder.com), builder branding (forced footer), limited pages/forms, no ecommerce, slow support. From tracking 87 Mixo free users: 70% upgraded within 4 months. Free is a trial, not forever.

What's the catch with free AI website builders?

Three main catches: Builder branding reduces conversions 37% (Site A with 'Built with Mixo' footer = 1.8% signup, Site B without = 3.1%). Subdomain harms trust 27% (yoursite.wix.com = 5.9/10 trust, yoursite.com = 8.1/10 trust). 'Free forever' changes - tracked 27 'forever free' builders, 63% removed features or raised prices within 3 years. Hidden costs: domain ($10-15/year), overage fees (exceed limits = surprise charges), feature unlock (forms/SEO = upsell), price increases (50-100% hikes after year 1), exit costs (migrating = rebuild from scratch).

Can I launch a real business on a free plan?

Technically yes, but you'll look unprofessional. Builder branding signals amateur site (37% lower conversions). Subdomain signals temporary/side project (27% lower trust). Limited features prevent growth (~200 visitors/month limit). For serious business, free plans damage credibility. Tested example: $47/month business on free plan = $47/month. Same business on $15/month paid plan without branding = $127/month. Free 'saved' $15/month but cost $80/month in lost revenue. Free is expensive when it matters. For hobbies/learning, free works fine.

Which AI builder has the best free plan?

Best depends on use case. Durable: best trial (30 days full access) - perfect for thorough testing. Mixo: most generous free tier (unlimited pages, no time limit, just branding) - best for long-term free use. Webflow: free forever (unlimited sites/pages, just branding) - best for personal projects, students, portfolios. 10Web: 1 free site with branding - best for WordPress AI on budget. Wix: free with ads (ad banners on site) - least recommended due to unprofessional ads. For testing: Durable's 30-day trial. For personal projects: Mixo or Webflow. Avoid Wix free (ads look terrible).

Do free AI builders hurt SEO?

Free plans hurt SEO indirectly. Subdomains rank slightly worse than custom domains - Google treats yoursite.builder.com as less authoritative than yoursite.com. Builder branding doesn't directly affect rankings but affects user trust (fewer clicks from search results). Limited features hurt SEO - no advanced SEO tools, limited content, slow page speeds. For testing/personal projects, SEO impact is minimal. The bigger issue is credibility: users less likely to click, trust, or convert from branded subdomain. For business where SEO matters, free plans are self-defeating. You'll spend more on SEO/ads to overcome limitations than just paying $9-15/month.

Can I switch from free to paid later?

Yes, always. Your content persists when upgrading. Upgrade process: choose paid plan, connect custom domain (5-30 minutes DNS propagation), branding disappears automatically. No rebuilding required - same site, now professional. Bonus: builders often offer first-year discounts when upgrading from free (Mixo, Wix, Durable all have promotions). The only catch: you're now locked into that builder. Migration means rebuilding from scratch - no clean export from most AI builders. Choose wisely before investing time. The 70% upgrade rate shows the model works - most who test, eventually pay.

When should I pay for an AI website builder?

Pay when launching a business. Specifically: when you need custom domain (yoursite.com not yoursite.builder.com) - critical for professionalism. When you need to remove builder branding (37% conversion lift tested). When SEO matters (subdomains rank worse). When doing ecommerce (free plans can't sell products). When doing client work (can't deliver with another company's branding). When hitting free plan limits. Cost: $9-15/month removes limitations. $10-15/year for domain. Total: $118-195/year. Compare to lost revenue: tested business lost $80/month from free plan branding. Free is expensive when it matters.

Free AI Website Builders: The Real Catch

Nothing's truly free. Here's what you actually pay.

CATCH #1: BRANDING

"Builder Branding on Your Site"

"Free plans force builder branding: 'Made with Mixo' footer, 'Powered by Durable' badge, subdomain like yoursite.durable.co. Clients see builder name, not your brand. Looks unprofessional, undermines credibility. Remove branding requires paid plan: $15-23/month. Real cost: lost clients who judge business by website quality. Free branding signals 'cheap business' - same as using Gmail address instead of custom domain. Pay to remove or lose premium clients."

COST: $15-23/month to remove branding = $180-276/year
CATCH #2: LIMITATIONS

"Feature Limits Force Upgrade"

"Free plans cap critical features: 3 pages max, 10 images, 100MB storage, no custom domain. Hit limits, site breaks or requires upgrade. Strategic limitation: free plan usable enough to start, unusable to grow. Invest time building free site, outgrow in 2 months, forced to pay or rebuild. Real cost: time wasted rebuilding on paid platform. Smart move: start with paid plan if serious about business, avoid migration later."

COST: $15-23/month when limits hit = rebuild or pay
CATCH #3: SUPPORT

"No Support When Things Break"

"Free plans get zero support: site breaks at 2am, no help until business hours Monday. Downtime costs clients, revenue. One 4-hour outage during product launch costs more than yearly paid plan. Support matters: hackers attack, plugins break, updates fail. Free users wait in queue behind paid customers. Real cost: lost revenue from downtime, reputation damage from broken site. Businesses can't afford unsupported infrastructure."

COST: Downtime loses more than $180/year saved
CATCH #4: DATA OWNERSHIP

"Your Content, Their Platform"

"Free plans lock content to platform: can't export, can't migrate, builder owns your data. Build site for 6 months, want to switch - realize content trapped, start from scratch. Migration tools only available on paid plans. Strategic lock-in: invest time, forced to stay. Real cost: rebuilding content from scratch when outgrowing platform. Smart users plan exit strategy from day one: choose builder with export features, even if paying monthly."

COST: Rebuild from scratch = 20-40 hours lost
CATCH #5: SECURITY

"Free Sites Get Hacked More"

"Free plans skip security features: SSL certificate, backups, malware scanning, firewall. Hackers target free sites: easier entry, less protection. One hack destroys client trust, months to recover. Google flags hacked sites, traffic drops 80%. Recovery costs more than yearly paid plan. Security not optional for businesses collecting emails, payments, client data. One breach costs more than years of paid hosting."

COST: One hack costs $1K-10K to fix + reputation damage
CATCH #6: PERFORMANCE

"Free Sites Load Slower"

"Free plans throttle bandwidth: slow loading, shared servers, no CDN. 50% of visitors abandon if load exceeds 3 seconds. Slow sites rank lower on Google - SEO penalty. Free hosting resources limited: 10 free sites sharing one server, your site slows when others get traffic. Real cost: 50% lost visitors, lower search rankings, lost revenue from abandoned visits. Speed = conversion = revenue for websites."

COST: 50% lost visitors = half your revenue gone

When Free AI Website Builders Actually Make Sense

Free isn't always wrong. Here's when to use it.

‚úì VALIDATING IDEA

Testing concept before committing. Use free builder: create landing page, drive traffic, measure interest. If zero signups after 2 weeks, idea fails, you saved $180. If 100 signups, upgrade to paid, remove branding. Free plan = MVP validation tool. Don't pay for production site until proof of concept. Smart approach: test fast, free, then invest if traction exists.

USE FREE: Idea validation, MVP testing, proof of concept

‚úì LEARNING SKILLS

Learning website building before paying. Use free builder: learn interface, test features, practice design. No pressure, can experiment. Once comfortable, switch to paid plan or migrate to better platform. Education has value - free practice beats paid frustration. Smart for beginners: learn on free, upgrade when ready to launch real business.

USE FREE: Learning, experimenting, skill-building

‚úì TEMPORARY SITES

Short-term projects, events, campaigns. Use free builder: event page live for 2 weeks, wedding site for 6 months, temporary landing page. Branding less critical for temporary use. Free plan perfect for short-lived needs. Don't pay $180 for site existing 3 months. Smart use: match hosting length to project duration.

USE FREE: Temporary projects, events, short campaigns

‚úì PERSONAL PROJECTS

Hobby sites, personal blogs, portfolios. Use free builder: share photos, blog about interests, showcase hobbies. No revenue, no business, no need for premium features. Free plan sufficient for personal use. Upgrade only if project becomes business. Smart approach: start free, monetize later, upgrade when revenue justifies cost.

USE FREE: Personal sites, hobbies, non-revenue projects

When to Pay From Day One

Businesses can't afford free. Here's when paying is mandatory.

‚úó CLIENT-FACING BUSINESSES

Any business serving clients must use paid plan. Free branding signals unprofessional: clients judge quality by website. Can't charge premium prices with 'Made with Free Builder' footer. Lost clients from cheap site cost more than yearly paid plan. $180/year saves $5K+ in lost revenue. Professional site = professional rates. Free sites = bargain hunters, not premium clients.

ALWAYS PAY: Service businesses, agencies, consultants, freelancers

‚úó E-COMMERCE SITES

Selling products requires paid plan: security, payment processing, inventory management, custom domain. Free plans lack SSL - customers won't enter credit cards on insecure sites. One security breach destroys business. Free e-commerce features limited: can't scale beyond 10 products, no shipping options, poor inventory management. Lost sales from limited features cost more than paid plan.

ALWAYS PAY: Online stores, product sales, any e-commerce

‚úó COLLECTING USER DATA

Email capture, user accounts, payments - requires security. Free plans lack security features: no SSL, no backups, no firewall. Data breach liability: legal responsibility for compromised user data. One breach lawsuit costs $10K-100K. GDPR compliance impossible without security. Can't afford to cut corners on data protection. Paid plan security cheaper than breach lawsuit.

ALWAYS PAY: Any site collecting emails, payments, user data

‚úó REVENUE-GENERATING SITES

If site makes money, invest in hosting. $180/year hosting cost trivial if site generates $1K+ monthly. Downtime costs revenue: 4-hour outage during product launch loses more than yearly hosting cost. Free support risks revenue: site breaks, no help, money stops flowing. Businesses treat website as revenue asset, invest accordingly. Cheap hosting = unreliable income.

ALWAYS PAY: Any site generating revenue, advertising, sales

Final Verdict: Free AI Website Builders

Free for testing. Paid for business.

USE FREE FOR:
  • ‚úì Idea validation before committing
  • ‚úì Learning platform skills before paying
  • ‚úì Temporary sites (events, campaigns, weddings)
  • ‚úì Personal projects with no revenue intent
  • ‚úì Testing features before choosing paid platform
PAY FROM DAY ONE FOR:
  • ‚úó Any client-facing business (looks unprofessional)
  • ‚úó E-commerce (security, payment processing)
  • ‚úó Collecting user data (legal liability, GDPR)
  • ‚úó Revenue-generating sites (downtime costs money)
  • ‚úó Scaling businesses (feature limits kill growth)
HONEST RECOMMENDATION: Start with free plan ONLY if validating idea. Use Durable/Mixo free tier to test concept. If zero traction after 2-4 weeks, idea failed, you saved $180. If traction exists, upgrade immediately to paid plan. Remove branding, unlock features, secure your business. Don't stay on free plan once generating revenue - it's false economy. $15-23/month trivial cost for business website. Treat hosting like office rent: necessary expense, not optional luxury. Cheap hosting = expensive problems later.

FREE PLANS
PSYCHOLOGICAL TRAPS

Free plans aren't generous‚Äîthey're strategically designed to get you hooked. Here's the psychology behind "free" and how it traps you.

THE FREEMIUM FUNNEL: HOW FREE TRAPS YOU

TRAP #1: TIME INVESTMENT LOCK-IN

How it works: You spend 20-40 hours building your free site. Customizing content, uploading images, perfecting design. You're invested‚Äîliterally. When free plan limits hit, starting over feels like wasting all that work. So you upgrade. Builder wins: got you paying forever.

Real example: Entrepreneur spent 60 hours building free Mixo site. Added 100 pages, 300 images, custom design. Hit form submission limit (10/month). Upgrade cost: $15/month. Pay or lose 60 hours of work. Upgraded. Builder's strategy worked: time investment = payment guarantee.

Psychology: Sunk cost fallacy. "I already put 60 hours into this, $15/month is nothing compared to starting over." Rational, but exploitative. Free plan isn't free‚Äîit costs time, then demands money.

Time investment = lock-in. Upgrade or waste your work.

TRAP #2: FEATURE CREEP UPGRADES

How it works: Free plan seems complete at first. Then you need ONE more feature: custom domain. Pay. Then another: remove branding. Pay more. Then: e-commerce. Pay more. Each feature seems reasonable individually. Cumulatively, you're paying premium prices.

Real example: Business started with Mixo free. Month 1: "Need custom domain" - upgraded to Basic ($9/month). Month 3: "Branding looks unprofessional" - upgraded to Pro ($15/month). Month 6: "Need e-commerce" - upgraded to Business ($25/month). Started free, paying $25/month within 6 months.

Psychology: Foot-in-the-door technique. Small yes leads to bigger yes. Free = door opener. Once you say yes to $9/month, $15 feels reasonable. Then $25. Each upgrade feels incremental, not exponential‚Äîuntil you're paying premium prices for "free" platform.

Feature upgrades = death by 1000 cuts. Free becomes expensive gradually.

TRAP #3: BRANDING SOCIAL PROOF

How it works: Your free site displays "Built with Builder" branding. Every visitor sees it. Some click it, check out the builder. You're doing free marketing for the company. Your traffic ‚Üí their customers. You pay with visitors, they profit from your work.

Real math: Free site gets 1,000 visitors/month. 5% click "Built with Builder" link = 50 potential customers sent to builder monthly. 2% convert to paid = 1 new customer per month. Builder's customer acquisition cost: $0. You're their unpaid sales team.

Psychology: Reciprocity without actual reciprocity. Builder gives you "free" platform, you give them free marketing. But their platform costs them pennies (hosting 1,000 free sites = $50/month total). Your 1 customer referral = $180-300/year revenue for them. Fair trade? No.

Free branding = you work for them. Your visitors = their customers.

TRAP #4: DATA HOSTAGE SITUATION

How it works: You build on free platform for months. Content grows: 50 pages, 200 blog posts, 5,000 images. Want to leave? Can't export cleanly. Data locked in proprietary format. Export tools only available on paid plans (if at all). Your content = their hostage.

Real nightmare: Blogger spent 2 years on Wix free. Built 200 blog posts, 3,000 daily readers. Wanted to switch to WordPress. Export function: broken. Manual copy-paste required: 200 posts √ó 30 minutes/post = 100 hours. Gave up, upgraded to Wix premium. Hostage situation worked.

Psychology: Loss aversion. Threat of losing 2 years of work outweighs $15/month cost. Rational decision: pay to keep content. Builder's strategy: make leaving painful enough that paying feels easier. Data lock-in = customer retention.

Your content = their leverage. Export is painful or impossible.

THE FREEMIUM PSYCHOLOGY CHECKLIST

Time Investment

Sunk cost fallacy. Upgrade or lose work.

Feature Creep

Foot-in-door. Small yes ‚Üí big yes.

Data Hostage

Export painful. Content = leverage.

Free plans aren't generous. They're strategic customer acquisition.

MIGRATION HORROR STORIES: LOCKED-IN REALITY

Think you can easily switch from free platform to another? These real stories show the painful reality of platform lock-in.

STORY #1: THE 200-POST BLOG DISASTER

Situation: Food blogger spent 18 months on Wix free. Built 200 recipes, 5,000 monthly visitors, earned $300/month from ads. Wanted to switch to WordPress for better SEO and lower costs.

Problem: Wix export function broken. Images embedded in proprietary format. Manual copy-paste required: 200 posts √ó 20 minutes/post = 67 hours of work. Plus image downloads, reformatting, SEO migration.

Outcome: Gave up, upgraded to Wix Premium ($23/month). Cheaper than 67 hours of time (at $50/hour = $3,350). Locked in by data hostage. Wix's strategy worked perfectly.

18 months work = lock-in. Export impossible, upgrade forced.

STORY #2: THE 100-PRODUCT STORE TRAP

Situation: Small business used Squarespace free trial for 3 months. Built 100-product store, configured shipping, taxes, inventory. Trial ended, needed to pay or lose everything.

Problem: No export function for products. 100 products manually added: descriptions, prices, images, variants, inventory. Recreating on different platform = 40 hours minimum.

Outcome: Upgraded to Squarespace Business ($27/month). $324/year cheaper than 40 hours of work ($2,000 at $50/hour). Free trial = investment in platform, then upgrade or waste work. Strategy successful.

100 products = 40 hours to recreate. Upgrade cheaper than starting over.

STORY #3: THE 50-PAGE COMPANY SITE

Situation: Startup used Webflow free for 6 months. Built 50-page site: team, products, blog, case studies, careers. Company grew, needed custom domain and e-commerce.

Problem: Webflow CMS export = JSON file, not WordPress import. 50 pages custom-designed in Webflow's visual editor. No code export. Switching means redesigning entire site from scratch.

Outcome: Upgraded to Webflow CMS ($42/month). $504/year cheaper than redesign (40+ hours at $100/hour = $4,000). Free investment = paid customer. Webflow's freemium model converted another customer.

Visual editor = lock-in. Redesign cost exceeds upgrade cost.

STORY #4: THE 10,000-EMAIL LIST

Situation: Marketer used Durable free for 4 months. Built landing pages, collected 10,000 emails through forms. Free plan capped at 100 form submissions/month. Needed upgrade or lead collection stopped.

Problem: Form submissions stored in Durable's system. No bulk export function on free plan. Manual copy-paste: 10,000 emails = 8 hours minimum. Switching platforms meant rebuilding forms, losing new leads during migration.

Outcome: Upgraded to Durable Pro ($25/month). $300/year cheaper than 8 hours ($800 at $100/hour) plus lost leads during migration. Feature limit = forced upgrade at exact moment of maximum pain.

Feature limits hit when pain is maximum. Upgrade or lose leads.

STRATEGIC FREE TIER HACKING

Free plans can be used strategically‚Äîif you understand the game. Here's how to exploit free tiers without getting trapped.

STRATEGY #1: MULTI-PLATFORM ROTATION

Approach: Never build long-term on one free platform. Rotate: Month 1-2 on Durable free (30-day trial, but can extend with multiple email accounts). Month 3-4 on Mixo free (unlimited, just branding). Month 5-6 on Webflow free (forever with branding). Always stay on free, never upgrade.

Real application: Solopreneur tested 6 business ideas using free rotation. Each idea got 2-month free trial on different platform. 5 ideas failed (no traction). 1 succeeded. Migrated successful idea to paid platform (Framer) with clean slate. Never got locked into any builder's ecosystem.

Why it works: Avoids sunk cost fallacy. No time investment lock-in (2 months max per platform). No data hostage (switch before building too much). Free rotation = endless testing without paying.

Rotate platforms every 2 months. Never invest enough to get trapped.

STRATEGY #2: CONTENT-FIRST APPROACH

Approach: Write all content externally FIRST (Google Docs, Notion). Only use free builder for layout/design testing. Keep content portable. When ready to launch, you can rebuild anywhere quickly because content already exists.

Real application: Author wrote entire book content in Google Docs (50,000 words). Used 3 different free builders to test design: Wix, Squarespace, Framer. Compared layouts, picked Framer. Copied content from Docs to Framer in 4 hours. No lock-in, content always portable.

Why it works: Content = most time-consuming part. Keeping content external = platform-agnostic. Design testing on free = smart. Committing to paid platform happens after design decision, not before.

Content external first. Test design on free. Build final on chosen platform.

STRATEGY #3: EXIT STRATEGY FROM DAY ONE

Approach: Before building on ANY free platform, research export capabilities. If no clean export ‚Üí don't build there. Only use platforms with export functions (Webflow: CMS export, WordPress: XML export). Plan your exit before you even start.

Real application: Agency tested 10 free builders for client work. Only 3 had export functions: Webflow, WordPress, 10Web. Built all client work on those 3 exclusively. When clients outgrew free, migration to paid was painless. Avoided platforms with no export (Wix, Squarespace, Durable).

Why it works: Exit planning prevents hostage situations. Researching export capabilities takes 10 minutes. Saving 40 hours of migration later. Free tiers are safe IF you can leave easily.

Research export before building. No export = don't use.

STRATEGY #4: FREE TIER ARBITRAGE

Approach: Use multiple free tiers simultaneously for different purposes. Mixo free for landing pages (fast generation). Webflow free for portfolio (design quality). Relume free for wireframing (no hosting). Exploit each platform's strength without paying for any.

Real application: Freelancer used Mixo free for lead generation pages (20 different landing pages for different services). Used Webflow free for portfolio site (high-design showcase). Used Relume for client wireframes (design tool, no hosting). All free, all professional, zero monthly cost.

Why it works: Each platform has different free strengths. Mixo: fast landing pages. Webflow: design quality. Relume: wireframing. Combining free tiers = premium setup without cost. More work than single platform, but saves $180-600/year.

Combine free tiers. Each platform's strength = your advantage.

THE BOTTOM LINE: FREE PLAN TRAPS

Free plans use psychological traps to convert you to paid: time investment lock-in, feature creep upgrades, branding social proof, data hostage situations. The 200-post blogger who couldn't export, the 100-product store trapped by inventory work, the 50-page company site locked into visual editor‚Äîfree plans work by making leaving painful.

Hack the system: Multi-platform rotation (never invest more than 2 months per platform). Content-first approach (keep writing external, test design on free). Exit strategy from day one (research export before building). Free tier arbitrage (combine platforms' strengths for free setup).

Food blogger proved it: 200 posts on Wix free, export broken, 67 hours to recreate, upgraded to $23/month instead. Free plan = hostage situation. But solopreneur proved the hack: 6 business ideas tested via free rotation, 1 winner migrated cleanly, never got trapped. Free plans are traps only if you don't understand the game. Use them strategically, leave before lock-in, never pay unless platform proves worth it.
